If all you're doing is using github, then you can use markdown, which would=

probably be a lot easier for people to edit.

If you will eventually be pu=
shing to junit.org, then you can at that point
use jekyll to generate the h=
tml.

Personally, I'd recommend using markdown.

Matthew Farwell.

2012/11/=

> https://github.com/scalastyle/scalastyle.github.=
com,
> > which is markdown. When I push to the repo, this updates

//scalastyle.github.com/ automatically. Then I use jekyll to
> generate
> >=
 an html site which I push to http://www.scalastyle.org. Thus I get
> exact=
ly
> > the same site on github and www.scalastyle.org.
> >

works well, because I want to have the two sites. You could

 a git hook to push to www.junit.org automatically.

're happy with junit.github.com, then you don't need

it repo.

nit.org was down for a

ts former self. That site has

light.com for several years, and by

t it recently had a rather nasty failure, and

=
> > > > Rather than spend a lot of effort recreating the old situation, I'd=

> like
> > > to
> > > > move us to a new situation, in which the team that=
 develops JUnit is

tion sources about JUnit.

github pages for JUnit ready to be a

org. These pages are hosted at

ey're currently pretty sad, but

l requests against

 Ideally, it would

description of what JUnit
> is,

oc, mailing list, and the wiki (
> > > > http://github.com/kentbeck/junit/w=
iki), which is itself incomplete,

> > > > getting better day by day a=
s a source of user documentation.
> > > >
> > > > If anyone feels like roll=
ing up their sleeves and give this a try, it

 step forward. I'm out of the office all next week, but am

> > to move quickly getting the pieces in place upon my return.

> >=
